pullRequest.body:
This PR defines the type `CstarVec n A` as a copy of `n ‚Üí A` meant for the case where `A` is a C‚ãÜ-algebra. This type is then given a Hilbert C‚ãÜ-module structure, namely an `A`-valued inner product and the norm `‚Äñv‚Äñ = ‚àö‚Äñ‚ü™v, v‚ü´‚Äñ`.

- [ ] depends on: #15244

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [85a8ec021b](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15274/commits/85a8ec021bf116b0dca6f373f3dbd535c92167d7)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.CStarVec`|1950|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ CStarVec`
`+ add_apply`
`+ ext`
`+ finset_sum_fn`
`+ inner_eq_sum`
`+ inner_single_left`
`+ inner_single_right`
`+ instAdd`
`+ instAddCommGroup`
`+ instAddCommMonoid`
`+ instAddGroup`
`+ instAddMonoid`
`+ instAddSemigroup`
`+ instCStarModule`
`+ instCoeFun`
`+ instInner`
`+ instModule`
`+ instNeg`
`+ instNorm`
`+ instNormedAddCommGroup`
`+ instNormedSpace`
`+ instSMul`
`+ instSub`
`+ instSubNegMonoid`
`+ instZero`
`+ instance : Bornology (CStarVec n A) := Pi.instBornology`
`+ instance : CompleteSpace (CStarVec n A) := Pi.complete _`
`+ instance : TopologicalSpace (CStarVec n A) := Pi.topologicalSpace`
`+ instance : UniformSpace (CStarVec n A) := Pi.uniformSpace _`
`+ instance [Inhabited A] : Inhabited (CStarVec n A)`
`+ neg_apply`
`+ norm_apply_le_norm`
`+ norm_eq_sqrt_sum`
`+ norm_single`
`+ norm_sq_eq_sum`
`+ ofFun`
`+ ofFun_apply`
`+ ofFun_symm_apply`
`+ smul_apply`
`+ sub_apply`
`+ such`
`+ zero_apply`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#15244~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ü§ñ). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

@dupuisf is there anything else that we should snag from this PR that I missed? Or should we close it? Or do you think we should still have `CStarVec` as an `abbrev` for `C‚ãÜ·µê·µí·µà (n ‚Üí A)` (which would be weird because it's actually longer given the notation!)?
No, I think we can just close this one.
Nice! Mainly naming issues. Some of the proofs seem overly hard, but I'm on mobile, so maybe I'm wrong!

I recently helped Jon Bannon fix some very annoying defeq abuse having to do with `EuclideanSpace ùïú n = n ‚Üí ùïú`. I'm sure whoever created it had no idea they were committing defeq abuse, and the reviewers just didn't notice. I guess what I'm wondering is this: should we make this an `@[irreducible] def` (or an `irreducible_def`) and just use `seal` / `unseal` when we really do want to see through the defeq (e.g., within this file)?

Yeah, I'm still not too sure what the best approach is here. I went with `irreducible` for `E ‚ÜíWOT[ùïú] F`, but then I saw that e.g. `PiLp` is even an abbrev to inherit all the instances from `WithLp`, and it doesn't seem to cause major problems (but maybe I just didn't see them). I actually went with `abbrev` for `CStarMatrix` also to inherit everything from matrices, basically copying the `PiLp` design.

Well, the `PiLp` bit is basically just to have nicer syntax. It's `WithLp` that is the type synonym barrier. That is a default def, neither abbrev nor irreducible. This is, essentially exactly what caused the issues in `EuclideanSpace` which is itself another `abbrev` for a `WithLp` variant. The problem is that Lean would see through `EuclideanSpace K n`, which is abbreviated for `WithLp 2 (n -> K)`, to bare functions `n -> K` if the user was ever so slightly sloppy. My thinking is that this is basically the same situation. So I'm convincing myself to advocate for irreducible. Especially success we can avoid pain whenever we need to with `unseal`. This way we keep the barrier tight and force users to use `ofFun` and the `CoeFun` instance, which is what they should be doing already to avoid defeq abuse.

I tried to convert this to `irreducible` and it's surprisingly painful. You can't just unseal every lemma that gives you trouble (stuff like `zero_apply` and friends), because once those things are defined via defeq with functions, you can't use them later when resealed. So you have to redo the whole hierarchy of `SubNegMonoid` and friends by hand with `ofFun`. I think this would work fine if we could state lemmas in "sealed mode" and then unseal only in the proof.
Aha, I see. Thanks for trying.

How about adding the `right` version of this too?
```suggestion
lemma inner_single_left [DecidableEq n] {v : CStarVec n A} {i : n} {a : A} :
```

And also add `norm_sq_eq_sum`?
```suggestion
lemma norm_eq_sqrt_sum {v : CStarVec n A} : ‚Äñv‚Äñ = ‚àö‚Äñ‚àë i : n, star (v i) * v i‚Äñ := rfl
```

Is this "entry" terminology used in other parts of the library? 
```suggestion
lemma norm_apply_le_norm [DecidableEq n] [CompleteSpace A] {v : CStarVec n A} {i : n} :
```
It's also used a bit in `Matrix`, but it arguably makes more sense there. But yeah, `apply` is a bit more consistent with the rest of mathlib here.

```suggestion
/-- A temporary "bad" instance of `NormedAddCommGroup` that induces a uniformity that is not
defeq with the product uniformity.

This is not intended for use outside of this file. -/
```
Ditto
Are these proofs essentially just copied from the analogous ones for `EuclideanSpace`?
No, I mostly looked at `PiLp` for inspiration for this file actually. I followed the same general strategy, but I reproved the Lipschitz/Antilipschitz from scratch.
What's this `rfl` unfolding?

I think there's some defeq abuse here. I have a PR forthcoming which will change the scope of this PR, and it should address this defeq abuse too. The key is to use the coercion to function manually, because otherwise Lean sees a function application, asks itself "is the type of the thing in the function position a function?", finds the answer is "yes", but commits defeq abuse doing so.

Does this work?
```suggestion
  have hmain :
      (fun x => star (if x = i then a else 0) * v x)
        = fun x => if x = i then star a * v x else 0 := by
    ext
    split_ifs with h <;> simp [h, mul_assoc]
  simp [inner_eq_sum, ofFun_apply, Pi.single_apply, hmain, Finset.sum_ite]
```

This could be
```suggestion
  inner_add_right {v w‚ÇÅ w‚ÇÇ} := by
```
according to your preference
I'm surprised you need the `apply Eq.symm` here. Am I missing something?

pullRequest.title: feat(CStarAlgebra): vectors with entries in a C‚ãÜ-algebra
